[h1]Half-Life: Source- New Engine, Same Game[/h1]
Half-Life: Source is a port of Half-Life 1 with a few improvements made using Valve's iconic Source engine. Unfortunately, this game doesn't offer much more than the 1998 classic already does. Sure, there's a few graphical improvements, some cool physics, and I can see through the surface of the water this time, but this Source "remaster" also comes with its fair share of bugs. 
A few of these bugs include: scientists and guards screaming repeatedly if they get injured, levitating guns/health kits, and the skybox in certain maps will distort if you look at the sky.
Asides from the minor improvements and bugs, this game contains the same epic journey that changed the FPS genre forever, including a level select (with every level already unlocked so you can skip right to Xen if you want) and more loading screens than before.

[b]Rating: A One-to-One Source Port That Could Have Done More[/b]
I'd have to rank Half-Life: Source at a 5/10. I can't recommend this game to anyone whose already played the 1998 classic. Only get it for the Garry's Mod assets. If you want a real remaster, check out the 2020 fan remake of Half-Life (called Black Mesa) made by Crowbar Collective. It may not be an official Valve game, but it certainly adds a whole lot more to Half-Life than this game did.

Crowbar now only makes the metal sound, that one scene [spoiler]when the HECU grunt is attacking the scientist[/spoiler] doesn't work.

This "remaster" is for you, if you have Garry's Mod, see all the bugs, or just want to have fun with impulse 101 and "crossbow-pinning" scientists. It's not worth your cash.

When I first started to get into Half Life, I admit I was pretty confused on what the difference between the game "Half Life" and "Half Life: Source" was. After some research, I figured out that Source is simply just a remastered version of Half Life that was released by Valve in 2005. Source is pretty much the same game as the original Half Life that was released in the 90's, just with some updated graphics and physics here and there.

After replaying Half Life: Source, I've encountered quite a few bugs, none of which hindered my progression in the game but were quite annoying. Despite its flaws, I have thoroughly enjoyed Half Life: Source and if you're a fan of classic games then I suggest you get it.

If you're thinking you're going to get a CS:S or DOD:S styled remake or remaster for HL1, which was originally a Gold Source game, you will be extremely disappointed. There's a huge cluster of glitches that are littered throughout, ranging from some being an small inconvenience that can agitate people (like the security guards and scientists moaning, screaming, and groaning constantly after getting hit), others being major bugs or exploits in the game play (biggest example being the tentacle encounter, which HL:S turns the menacing alien tentacles that could possibly kill you in one hit if you're not careful, into decoration).

Look I know we got purists in this house that are like "UGUGUGUh If YOU play SOURCE YOU HAVE WASTED YOUR MONEY, COMPLETELY AWFUL AND UNPLAYABLE-" But like. Listen. From my personal experience, it plays just fine? Of course I've never played the original, so I wouldn't know, but I don't particularly care? It works fine? I also bought it on discount when it was cheaper than a bag of chips, so I'm diffidently getting my money's worth as long as it boots up. Literally had somebody straight up try to lecture me about all the things that suck in source, but their first point was literally that the crowbar sounds are different. if your frustrations are literally that miniscual, the source port was never going to satisfy you, and even if they patched in every single change you wanted like jesus descending down from heaven to bless you on Christmas morning, you would still be an ungrateful brat. but what do I know, I never played gold source, maybe it's like your boss handing you the keys to a brand new car and making you the CEO and your wife wants to rekindle the flames of your failing marriage and makes everything right in the world. probably still wouldn't play it out of spite at this point.

((Edit: loving the people in the comments failing to cope in peace over my unpopular opinion in the comments. really helping to sell me on the original here, guys. gg, still not gonna read your paragraph and buy the game.))

There isn't much of a difference between this game and the original Half-Life. If you're deciding which to buy, it honestly doesn't matter. The water is nicer in this game and there are ragdolls and better physics. Other than that, it's essentially the same game. Don't worry about not getting the "pure" experience of HL1 because this is essentially it. Lower resolution water and people who just lay down and die without leaving a ragdoll for you to smack with a crowbar weren't the cornerstones of the Half-Life. Playing HL is an experience, regardless of trivialities such as this.

I wouldn't get this by itself personally; if you really wanna pick it up, get it via one of the packs in the Store and/or wait for a sale.

One interesting note though, you can load up the content from this game in Garry's Mod. If you have Gmod, this might give you some fun stuff to play around with.

Based on the information provided, can you guess what game this review is for? What's it about? What kind of game is it?

Point is, these reviews are completely interchangeable. I bet if you took this exact review, and copy and pasted it to every game in your library, you'd get the top review for half of the games you put it on, even if you didn't change the check marks to fit each individual game.

In my opinion, the Steam community should stop encouraging this format and instead downvote them all into oblivion. Maybe it's just me, and I guess it's not THAT big a deal, but for someone that puts at least some effort into the reviews they write, it is a little disheartening that the steam community prefers lazy checklists that ultimately don't say anything specific about the games in question. Plus I don't see how they could ever actually influence someone's decision to purchase a game or not when so little information is given.

Anyone agree or am I the only one that wants to read legitimately helpful reviews for games I might be interested in?
A horrible port of Half Life that only gets worse and worse as time goes on.

My introduction to Half-Life series was in the year 2000 on computer science lessons in school (I must have been 7). But I played only deathmatch and not single-player mode back then. It was much later and after I already completed Half-Life 2 in the middle of 2000s, when I finally have beaten Half-Life 1. The series are very important to me and while I like Half-Life 2 the most, the very first game also holds an important place in my heart. The story of Half-Life 1 is not the most original. However, the way how it's written and portrayed it's what makes it so good and revolutionary. There was no cut-scenes in the game and we were watching everything from the eyes of our protagonist Gordon Freeman. It was only much later that such way of storytelling became common in videogame industry. The fact that Gordon was a theoretical physicist and not military or someone like Duke Nukem was interesting and original plot element (but obviously, it can be questioned how he knows how to operate all the weapons then). It's also worth to mention that Valve took inspirations in famous novel "The Mist" of legendary Stephen King while writing the story. So, today, if you are considering to experience this classics, you can choose either this version, the original or Black Mesa. But the last one is remake with many things changed/added. So, if you want to go closer to original, you shall choose either the original itself or this source version. And it would be clever decision to pick this one. Despite all the claims about bugs and so on, it has also its own advantages and is playable. As for me, as a series fan I like all the versions and I must also note that Black Mesa is a very good remake indeed and is absolutely worth playing.

En el a√±o 2025 Gabe Newell vende los derechos de la franquicia Half-Life al conglomerado formado por la fusi√≥n entre EA y Ubisoft. El juego est√° protegido por DRM de grado militar que secuestra las funciones m√°s bajas de su computadora y requiere una combinaci√≥n de ADN, retina y escaneo de huellas dactilares cada 2 minutos para poder jugar. El c√≥digo tambi√©n contiene una especie de protecci√≥n de "hielo negro" que, al detectar cualquier intento de romper el DRM, hace que todos los dispositivos electr√≥nicos del mundo apunten implacablemente al cracker para alg√∫n tipo de muerte ir√≥nica del tipo "Destino final".

El juego en s√≠ consiste √∫nicamente en una vista en primera persona de una mano empu√±ando una palanca, que se usa para romper cajas de bot√≠n abiertas. Las cajas cuestan $50 cada una y contienen una variedad de diferentes mejoras cosm√©ticas para su mano, palanca y cajas de bot√≠n.

Vendi√≥ diez mil millones de copias, y la UbEA reci√©n formada utiliz√≥ parte de sus ganancias para adquirir un misil bal√≠stico intercontinental nuclear de los saud√≠es, que utilizaron para destruir la sede del CDPR, pocas horas antes del lanzamiento programado de Witcher 5.

Adem√°s, por alguna raz√≥n, Valve cierra y Steam no te permite descargar tus juegos antes de cerrarlos como dijeron que har√≠an.
